title: Greenhaven: Heat & Flood Challenge
summary: Greenhaven is facing hotter summers and increasingly severe storm floods. As the city's decision-maker, you must allocate limited resources to redevelop two vulnerable neighborhoods while balancing costs, equity, and stakeholder satisfaction.

personaGoals.City Council: Oversees city planning, cares about efficiency & budget

briefing:
Welcome to Greenhaven. Two neighborhoods—Downtown and Riverside—are under pressure from rising temperatures and storm flood risks. Riverside has a higher proportion of vulnerable residents, while Downtown hosts dense businesses and offices.

You have a budget of $5M to implement interventions such as green roofs, rain gardens, shade trees, permeable pavements, or grey infrastructure like storm drains and concrete channels.

Your decisions will affect heat reduction, flood mitigation, equity, and stakeholder satisfaction. No solution is perfect—every choice has trade-offs, and consequences unfold over time.

Your task: allocate interventions, respond to stakeholder feedback, and maintain your city's credibility. Make the right call.

title: Solar Fields or Food Fields?
summary: The city of Sunhaven is under pressure to expand renewable energy. A major developer proposes a 400-acre solar farm on prime agricultural land outside the city. While this could power thousands of homes and slash emissions, farmers and food security advocates warn that sacrificing farmland will raise food prices and erode rural livelihoods.

personaGoals.City Council: Wants climate goals met and a big win for clean energy
personaGoals.Farmers' Association: Furious about losing farmland; worried about their future
personaGoals.Environmental NGO: Supports renewables but demands biodiversity safeguards
personaGoals.Local Residents: Split—cheaper power is attractive, but many fear higher food costs and land loss
personaGoals.Solar Developer: Focused on profit and fast build-out; wants minimal restrictions
personaGoals.Food Security Advocates: Deeply opposed to farmland loss; argue rooftop and brownfield projects first

briefing:
You've been tasked with evaluating whether Sunhaven should convert farmland into a solar farm or explore alternatives (rooftop panels, brownfield installations, or smaller distributed solar arrays). You must balance the need for clean energy with the region's food supply, rural economy, and community well-being.

Funding is capped at $10M, though you may overspend up to 20%—but beware of long-term debt fallout.

Energy need: 150 MW shortfall projected in 5 years.

Solar farm proposal: 400 acres, $8M cost, 120 MW output, 200 temporary construction jobs.

Alternative 1: Rooftop panels program - $10M cost, 80 MW output, 500 jobs across installation & maintenance.

Alternative 2: Brownfield solar - $7M cost, 60 MW output, requires soil cleanup first (delays 2 years).

Agricultural value of land: Annual food output feeds 50,000 people, value $3M annually. Projected population growth: +15% in 10 years.

Your task: weigh the trade-offs, allocate resources, and make the right call.

title: Urban green space development

personaGoals.City Planner: Create accessible green space for residents
personaGoals.Real Estate Developer: Maximize property value and tax revenue
